awd_titl_txt: SCC-IRG Track 2: Resilient Water Systems: Integrating Environmental Sensor Networks and Real-Time Forecasting to Adaptively Manage Drinking Water Quality and Build Social Trust
awd_abstract_narration:
1737424 (Carey). The freshwater lakes and reservoirs that provide the majority of Americans with their drinking water face increasing threats to water quality. Nutrient pollution, contaminants, and land use change can lead to low oxygen concentrations and algal blooms, which can result in elevated metal concentrations, fish and bird kills, thick algal scums, noxious odors, and overall toxic water unsafe for drinking. These adverse outcomes may be prevented if drinking water managers have the information needed to act preemptively. To increase the resilience of water supplies, this project will develop a smart water system that integrates smart and connected (S&C) technology and adaptive management to ensure safe drinking water for communities. The smart water system will consist of sensor networks embedded in a drinking water reservoir to reduce delays and enhance feedbacks between the detection of water quality degradation and decisive management action to mitigate such threats. This increased capacity to ensure sustained water quality can in turn build both public confidence and meaningful engagement with drinking water institutions. This project will connect the networks of high-frequency sensors with secure cyberinfrastructure to develop innovative, real-time water quality prediction models and tools for more effective management. Finally, these models will be used to educate local residents and students about the use of S&CC technology to manage their drinking water.
 
By embedding an integrated sensor network in a drinking water reservoir, this project integrates expertise from nine disciplines to study the complete feedback loop of how S&C technologies can improve drinking water management, water quality, and ultimately community well-being. The project will use novel sensor technology to monitor a drinking water supply reservoir and its catchment, and to develop and evaluate a new model-data fusion approach that will advance the field of environmental forecasting. These forecasts will be used to create decision-making tools for reservoir managers that will be evaluated for their usability. In addition, teaching materials will be developed to create a curriculum that exposes high school students to data emerging from S&C technology and increase their interest in and preparedness for careers in STEM. Finally, the project will assess public perception of the adoption and use of S&CC technologies by utilities to improve drinking water quality as well as the relationship between this perception, trust in the utility, and acceptance of the S&CC technology. This enhanced understanding and confidence may lead to increased social capital, permitting an evaluation of the degree to which S&CC technologies can increase both ecosystem resilience of drinking water quality in supply reservoirs and community resilience by increasing the public's trust in their water systems.

por.por_cntn:
The major outcome from this project is the creation of a novel water quality forecasting system that provides real-time forecasts of future lake and reservoir conditions for water managers. This system, called FLARE (Forecasting Lake And Reservoir Ecosystems), explicitly combines human interactions with smart and connected (S&C) technology into the full feedback loop of physical, technical, and social subsystems. FLARE is a novel integration of high-frequency sensor data, simulation modeling, real-time water quality forecasting, and manager decision support tools within a robust and secure cyberinfrastructure. This cyberinfrastructure operates an end-to-end automated workflow to collect sensor data from the reservoir and trigger the daily execution of forecasts in the cloud. This workflow includes: reading data from sensors in the reservoir and watershed; pushing daily updates to a cloud data repository; downloading and statistically-downscaling meteorological forecasts; cleaning sensor data; triggering the execution of ensemble models for uncertainty quantification; generating visualization plots and notifications to stakeholders; and publishing forecasts and data products. 

Our team of computer scientists, environmental scientists, engineers, social scientists, educators, and water managers worked closely together to develop FLARE and advance discipline-specific and interdisciplinary S&C research. Notable insights included: 1) the development of a virtual private networking system that connected environmental sensors in rugged field settings to the cloud for automated data collection and modeling; 2) greater understanding of how to build social trust in water utilities to increase the resilience to external water supply threats; 3) quantification of the predictability of freshwater ecosystems and water quality to climate change; 4) new tools for calculating and analyzing the drivers of uncertainty in ecological forecasts; 5) new statistical methods and applications of model-data fusion for hydrodynamic models; and 6) the creation of teaching modules that use water quality data from our S&C sensor network to teach undergraduate students about the effects of climate change on lakes, simulation modeling, and quantitative “big data” skills. 

Importantly, we deployed FLARE on a drinking water supply reservoir in Virginia and thoroughly tested the ability of the system to generate 1 to 16-day ahead forecasts every day over four years. We found that the forecasting system correctly predicted multiple water quality impairment events 4-14 days in advance, which improved drinking water management and the ability of a water utility to handle rapidly-changing environmental conditions. In recognition of our work, our forecasting system was highlighted in the October 2021 U.S. National Academy report to the National Science Foundation on “Next Generation Earth Systems Science.” The system is scalable to other lakes and reservoirs, and our team is partnering with other research groups for additional deployments. All sensor data are published in the Environmental Data Initiative repository, all FLARE code is publicly available in Zenodo and GitHub, and all documentation for deploying FLARE is available for download at www.flare-forecast.org. 

This project has provided interdisciplinary training to 23 undergraduate students, 16 graduate students, 4 technicians, 6 postdoctoral researchers, and 9 faculty. In total, our team has disseminated our research findings, forecasting system, and teaching module materials through 143 presentations at over 41 conferences and 30 invited presentations. We partnered with the Ecological Forecasting Initiative, Environmental Data Initiative, and Global Lake Ecological Observatory Network to disseminate our findings, and have led 8 training workshops for early career researchers and water quality managers. Moreover, we have given invited presentations to several federal agencies and NGOs, including NOAA, EPA, and the U.S. National Academy of Sciences. In total, this project has provided the context for 37 publications, 3 Ph.D. dissertations, and 2 M.S. theses.
